abstract: <jats:p>Results from a snap-shot survey of Dacine fruit flies carried out on three of the Solomon Islands in April 2018 are reported. Using traps baited with the male lures cue-lure, methyl eugenol, and zingerone, 30 of the 48 species previously known to occur in the Solomon Islands were collected. Six species are newly described here: <jats:italic>Bactrocera allodistincta</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>B. geminosimulata</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>B. kolombangarae</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>B. quasienochra</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>B. tsatsiai</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, and <jats:italic>B. vargasi</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, all authored by Leblanc &amp; Doorenweerd. An illustrated key to the 54 species now known to be present in the country is provided.</jats:p>
title: Novel lures and COI sequences reveal cryptic new species of Bactrocera fruit flies in the Solomon Islands (Diptera, Tephritidae, Dacini)
